I think the hon. member is trying to do indirectly what the Standing Orders will not allow him to do directly, that is to question the Speaker's ruling. The previous speaker was to my left, so I looked right. I am glad to recognize the hon. member for Edmonton South West.

Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House
of Commons): Mr. Speaker, I think our friends opposite, having had a little practice over the last few days, have decided they like to shout and barrack.
I have a few questions for my hon. friend for Papi-neau-Saint-Michel who has contributed so much to the constitutional process in our country over the last dozen years or more.

June 4, 1992
Government Orders
I appreciate what he said about the detailed study of this bill which took place in committee. I did a totalling of the hours in committee and it sat in excess of 18 hours over three days. It heard from the Minister and the Deputy Minister of Justice and later on from the three expert witnesses. Finally, there was the long day of 11 virtually uninterrupted hours doing the clause by clause study. He contributed an immense amount to the success of the bill in committee.
The hon. member referred to the NDP members' position on this bill and like him, I respect their position. But I am a little sorrowful about it because it gives the appearance the NDP members may be opposed to the holding of a referendum although we know that is not their intention. I wonder if he might undertake to use his good offices to persuade his neighbours to perhaps change their minds between now and 4.45 p.m. when we vote.
On the questions of substance on the Liberal position, I wonder if my hon. friend could comment a little further on the four regional majorities idea his party has advocated consistently for some time. Beaudoin-Dobbie advocated there be a consulted referendum but without regional majorities. My friend and I worked on a committee the previous year that recommended those majorities. He will recall there were provinces that immediately rejected the idea and said it violated the idea of provincial equality. They said it moved in the direction of regions on which this country was not built.
I wonder if he would comment on the positions of Alberta and Newfoundland in particular on that issue and on the more recent development that British Columbia regards itself as a fifth region. Has he consulted with his colleague and desk mate from Vancouver Quadra on that issue to learn what the British Columbia position would be?

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order please. I must interrupt the hon. speaker because many other speakers want to raise questions to the hon. member.

Mr. Speaker, I would be glad to answer the hon. member's question and to explain very briefly why we are talking about regional majority in this country.
You have to acknowledge that Canada is one of the most decentralized countries there is. Throughout the years, provincial premiers have gained in importance and
influence like none of their counterparts elsewhere in the world. You just have to compare the influence of a provincial premier with that of a governor in the United States to see how our premiers have become omnipresent and important in our political process. It has reached a stage where it took us almost 50 years to patriate the Canadian Constitution. Why? Because at the federal-provincial conferences, the Prime Minister of Canada could never reach an agreement with the premiers, who were just trying to get benefits for their own province, always to the detriment of the central government.
We, in the Liberal Party think that to leave the final decision to the people is one way to put an end to this inevitable trench war between the Prime Minister and the premiers. It is only natural that a premier would defend the interests of his province and demand the best for his people at a federal-provincial conference, but what is best for his province is not necessarily what is best for the whole country.
That is why we think that if we ask the people, all Canadians as Canadians, to vote on this question and if we get a majority in each of the major regions of the country, then the will and the common sense of the people will prevail, not the provincial or regional interests of the premiers.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member told us this bill was not legally binding and that it was merely consultative. Many members on the government side have told us the same thing. It is what we were told in 1942, before the referendum on conscription. The Prime Minister at the time used a crystal ball and consulted his dog before making decisions.
It was Mackenzie King.

Perhaps they were better than our Prime Minister's current advisers, who in many cases are the same people who advised the former Prime Minister, Mr. Trudeau.
I get the impression the purpose of this referendum is to sabotage the Quebec process. Time allocation is being used to restrict debate on this bill, but the hon. member says "I will support it, although I have a number of reservations". His party did not support Meech Lake, especially his leader with his "thank you, Clyde", as he said, although that exercise was supposed to save Canada. They had reservations, and they did not support Meech. I fail to see the logic in all this.
June 4, 1992

I wish the hon. member would answer the following question: If we recognize Quebec's right to self-determination, would it not make more sense for this Parliament and the other legislatures to put offers on the table? When a referendum is held under Bill 150, would it not make sense for federalists in Quebec to use these offers to say: "Vote no to sovereignty"? I think it would because the process would recognize the right to self-determination.
When all is said and done, I wonder whether the hon. member feels confident enough to face Quebec's federalist leadership, starting with Premier Bourassa. Is that not the real problem? Is that not why they want to sabotage the process? Do they think the federalist leadership in Quebec is incapable of defending the federalist option because it feels uncomfortable if no offers or only unacceptable offers are forthcoming?
Mr. Speaker, first of all, I will say that Mackenzie King must have a very good adviser, since he was Prime Minister for 23 years.
Yes, his dog.

I would also like to say to the hon. member for Laurier-Ste. Marie that, like so many Quebecers who want to see Quebec separate from Canada, he is sadly mistaken when he deliberately perpetrates the myth that the Leader of the Liberal Party was the one who prevented Meech, because that is just not true.
It is.

If the leader of the Bloc Quebecois had been a little more frank in his disclosures, a little more "A visage decouvert", he would have told us he was one of the people responsible for the demise of Meech Lake. He left the Conservative Party even before the Meech Lake Accord was rejected. He sabotaged the process that had been started to save Meech when he made his sensational exit from the Tory government.
Government Orders
At the very moment the parliamentary committee chaired by the Minister of the Environment was making recommendations that might have saved Meech, the leader of the Bloc, probably anxious to see the accord fail, left the Conservative Party. I imagine, and I say this with regret, that if he had not left the ranks of the Conservative Party, it probably would have been much easier to get an agreement on Meech at the time. However, by leaving the party and doing what he did, he precluded any possibility of an agreement.
Today in Parliament, with the exception of the hon. member for Laurier-Ste. Marie, whom I respect because he was properly elected, while his colleagues who crossed the floor and have no mandate from their constituents to take the kind of position they are taking, these people are trying to break up the country. I say to them that Quebecers want -

Order, please. The period for questions and comments is over.
[English)

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to be able to speak at third reading on the bill before us, Bill C-81, an act to provide for the possible holding of referendums in Canada.
I listened with care to the interventions that preceded this, and in particular to that of the hon. Leader of the Opposition who said a couple of things I wish to comment on. He said, first of all, a referendum is not proposed as a deadlock-breaking mechanism. I am sure he was not contemplating the government would use it as such.
I think all parties whose members have subscribed to this idea and to this legislation are holding to the recommendations of Beaudoin-Edwards and Beaudoin-Dobbie, which have identical wordings. "We recommend that a federal law be enacted to enable the federal government at its discretion to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal either to confirm the existence of the national consensus, or to facilitate the adoption of the required amending resolutions." That is not a deadlock-breaking mechanism. It is a facilitative mechanism.
The hon. Leader of the Opposition went on to say, and I believe this is a direct quote: "Whatever happens, there will be a referendum". That is not the intention of the government. The government would much rather this process be seen to a successful conclusion without the holding of a referendum.

June 4, 1992
Government Orders
The whole purpose of having this bill proclaimed into law, as I hope it will be soon, is to be able to use the device of a referendum if absolutely necessary. Mackenzie King was quoted just a moment or so ago, and I would say a referendum if necessary, but not necessarily a referendum, to paraphrase that Canadian statesman.
As colleagues have said, there was very detailed discussion in committee. The bill does not say a referendum must be held or how it should be interpreted. There were 29 amendments proposed in committee. Thirteen of those were accepted in committee or at report stage, and as my hon. friend from Papineau-Saint-Michel has said, seven out of the twelve were Liberal amendments.
It is correct, as the hon. House leader was saying, that there are rather strict limitations on what can be done in the context of 1992 as opposed, for example, to 1980 in the sense we are operating within the atmosphere of a charter today. The freedom of association issue as well as the freedom of speech issue have to be dealt with.
If there are to be umbrella committees that happen voluntarily then that is fine. They presumably would work if they were made to work, but it is our belief to mandate them would be unconstitutional and in some ways perhaps absurd.
With reference to the consultation on the question, I would like to point out not only did we provide a public undertaking to consult the leaders of the recognized parties in the House as opposition parties had requested, but we went a step further. We made that commitment in the bill itself, so it is required now by law as well as by moral commitment, or will be when the bill is proclaimed.
On the issues of financing and the definition of expenses, we have taken the concerns of Canadians into account and have gone a step toward the aboriginal peoples of Canada to make sure the text of the question will be available where appropriate in aboriginal languages.
I would like for a moment to deal with the proposed amendment which was defeated last night and which had
been offered by my hon. friend, the member for Etobicoke- Lakeshore. It is an issue that has puzzled a number of people. What is the appropriate word to describe what we have before us? Is it a plebiscite or a referendum?
Some study on the issue indicates that the word "referendum" and its French equivalent referendum are much more widely understood and accepted, at least in Canada, than the words "plebiscite" and plebiscite. That is particularly the case in the French language. The French word plebiscite is usually given a different meaning. The Quebec legislation which is la Loi sur la consultation populaire uses the term referendum. Using another term in the federal legislation might lead to confusion. To avoid this confusion we might have to use the word referendum in French even if we agreed to the change proposed by my friend, the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore, in the English version of the bill. While that may be technically correct in French, it might lead to a different type of confusion which we would all like to avoid.
I had the opportunity to meet an international expert on referendums, Professor Francis Delperee of the University of Louvain in Belgium. He has put together one of the most definitive works on the subject. It is titled simply Referendum and has several articles from many countries that have had referendum experience.
I will quote from the Canada section of that work. The article was written by our distinguished colleague from the other place, the hon. Senator Gerald Beaudoin:

There are several types of consultative or deliberative referendums. In the first, the people are consulted; in the second, the people participate in the legislative process. Furthermore, the referendum can be optional or required. In Canada, because the Constitution is silent on this point, referendums are optional.

In other words, the word "referendum" is used in the article by Senator Beaudoin exclusively. He, I submit, is one of the resident authorities.
June 4, 1992

However, I was not content to stay with Senator Beaudoin in investigating this issue. I purchased yesterday a book called The People's Mandate: Referendums in a More Democratic Canada by Patrick Boyer who is the very member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore who had proposed the amendment. I am quoting from page 23 of that book:

Mr. Speaker, the Government House Leader is talking about some very important matters and I see that there is no quorum in this House. I would ask you to take the count.
And the count having been taken

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I want to reassure the hon. member that there is indeed a quorum.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I am quoting from this book by my friend for Etobicoke-Lakeshore at the bottom of page 23: "Legally, a referendum is binding on a government, whereas a plebiscite is not. Expressed in slightly broader terms, the distinction that ought to be drawn is that a referendum in its legal meaning is a binding verdict of the people that must be reflected in a law or action by the government, whereas a plebiscite is a formalized expression of public opinion that can serve to guide the government on a specific issue or question".
My friend for Etobicoke-Lakeshore, in proposing his amendment which was defeated last night, no doubt was using his own argument. However, he said in making his argument that those were legal definitions. I then sought to find some authority, since there is no authority cited in his book. In Petit Robert, the definition of-

Plebiscite: a direct yes or no vote by the electorate. [English]
There is no question as to whether it is binding or not. The definition from Petit Robert:

Referendum: vote by all the citizens to approve or reject a measure proposed by the executive authority.
Government Orders

Again, there is no definition as to whether it would be binding or simply advisory.
Here is the definition of a plebiscite from The Shorter Oxford English Dictionary: "A direct vote of the whole of electors of a State to decide a question of public importance; also by extension, a public expression, with or without binding force, of the wishes or opinion of a community".
The definition of a referendum in that book is: "The act, practice, or principle... of submitting the direct decision of a question at issue to the whole body of voters. Again, there is no question as to whether it would be binding or not.
Perhaps Black's Law Dictionary is a more authoritative voice on the definition of plebiscite: "A vote of the entire people-expressing their choice for or against a proposed law or enactment, submitted to them, and which, if adopted, will work a radical change in the constitution, or which is beyond the powers of the regular legislative body.
Finally, here is the definition of a referendum from that book: "The process of referring to the electorate for approval a proposed new state constitution or amendment or of a law passed by the legislature".
I would submit that the issue was, of course, resolved for us last night by the defeat of my friend's motion. I know he had hoped to be here today to speak to the issue. I hope I have done some service by addressing the issue on his behalf. I will now deal with the broader issue of this bill and what it will put into effect. This bill will put into motion a challenge to the Chief Electoral Officer of Canada to begin preparing for the possibility of a referendum, presumably at a later date, but more likely this year if one is to be held.
The Chief Electoral Officer has informed the government and has testified in committee that it will take him a minimum of three months to set the machinery up for holding a referendum. Therefore, there is some anxiety on this side of the House and I know it is shared by members opposite. We want to see that the bill gets proper attention, but that it is also dealt with expeditiously.

June 4, 1992
Government Orders
I greatly appreciate the co-operation of members of the Official Opposition and the representative of the New Democratic Party on the legislative committee who worked so hard to see that the bill was improved at committee stage.
The question which will be put, as I suggested earlier, will be discussed fully with the leaders of the recognized opposition parties and will, of course, be debated in three days of debate in this House and three days of debate in the Senate. It is contemplated that the question which will be put will thus be the will, not only of the officially recognized parties, but also of this Parliament. That is a lot of time for debate.
It is, of course, a question which will have gone through the crucible with the provinces, the territories and other constituent groups. The hon. Leader of the New Democratic Party referred earlier to the aboriginal peoples. There is input being received on an almost daily basis on this issue and, ultimately, the question. What will precede the framing of the question will be a resolution of the House of Commons and the Senate which will again be brought to both Houses for debate after the response to the Beaudoin-Dobbie report as tabled by the government. This is after the successful conclusion, one would hope, of the discussions or the conferences with the provinces, the territories and the aboriginal leadership. I believe this is due to resume in a matter of days.
The response to what has been going on in this House and in committee over the last few days, I think, has been quite positive. The reaction and the interest of the Canadian people has been engaged. We have received a good deal of feedback in our own offices about the referendum legislation. There are many who were asking us to please get on with it, please have it there and please have it available as an option if it is required.
They are puzzled by the voices of those who seem to oppose the idea of a referendum and they are profoundly puzzled by those who suggest that this referendum is an anti-democratic procedure. They are completely flabbergasted that-
This bill.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
-that suggestion would be made.
My friend says: "This bill". This bill could not be more democratic. It is framed with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms in mind. It is framed to give maximum opportunity to Canadians to express their points of view.
The power of money.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
My friend says it is open to the use of money.
We had an interesting discussion with the Leader of the New Democratic Party earlier in the House on the question of money. I challenged her because she was quoting studies in the United States that said that candidates for Congress had been more successful when large amounts of money were spent on their campaigns. That may well be the case.
However, to transliterate that right back to the Canadian experience is very difficult to do and I challenged her to-
Free trade.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
The free trade debate. I challenged her on that very subject and asked if there were any studies that she could point to that would demonstrate that there was a linkage between anybody's expenditure in the free trade debate, on one side or the other, and the results of the 1988 election. She was not able to provide me with any through either the comic book of the CLC or any other campaign that was mounted.
The reaction has been generally positive. I quote from today's edition of The Gazette in Montreal: "The Mulro-ney government need not apologize for using its majority to pass a bill authorizing a national referendum on constitutional change. It is a crude move, but it has to be done and it has to be done quickly. Ottawa has the right to give itself the legislative tools it may need to try to break the constitutional deadlock. It has the duty to acquire the tools by urgent means because the country faces urgent deadlines".
That is a statement of reality and I think that Canadians from Quebec and from other parts of the country are very much awake to the urgent reality that is facing us.
The Gazette goes on to say: "The bill is just an enabling bill or legislation to enable the federal government to hold a national referendum on a question of its choosing and to set certain conditions for the vote".
June 4, 1992

Mr. Speaker, that is an interesting quote from The Gazette that the hon. parliamentary secretary just read us. Now, if his colleague, Mr. Loiselle, could hand him this morning's edition of Le Soleil, he would see that they call it a "referendum bluff". It might help him understand how we perceive this bill in Quebec.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: That was not a point of order. The hon. member for Edmonton Southwest has one minute left.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
My friend knew what I was coming to when he interrupted. What I was coming to was this. I am quoting The Gazette again:
Bloc Quebecois members merely cover themselves with ridicule
when they attack this inoffensive bill as "an illegitimate, antidemocratic holdup" and compare its supporters to "Cains" and "Nazi
collaborators" -
In fact, the bill is just an instrument that Ottawa may need to break a deadlock, to respect Quebec's democratic agenda, and to consult all the people on matters affecting the future of the whole country. No one this side of the lunatic fringe would contest that objective.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the member for Edmonton Southwest and he was referring to several learned texts during his speech. I would like to come back to The People's Mandate: Referendums and a More Democratic Canada written by the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore. I believe this book just came on the market in the last two days.
One of the criticisms we have been hearing from the Bloc Quebecois is the fact this bill has been put through here in a rather hasty fashion. Of course one of the arguments they have been advancing is the fact very few Canadians, and I am sure they do not mean just Quebecers, really understand all of the ramifications of the bill or just referendums in general.
I must say to the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader, there are many members in this House who do not have the understanding of all
Government Orders
aspects of this referendum legislation and what it means. It has been studied by the member for Etobicoke-Lake-shore for many years. He is an expert on it and we all acknowledge that in this House.
Would it not be a good idea for the Government of Canada, in its effort to assist Canadians who it wants to participate fully in this debate, to consider maybe having this book translated and making it available not only in every region of this country, but in high schools, colleges and community centres? In this way we can educate as many Canadians as possible over the next 30 or 40 days, as it takes a 90-day period to prepare for the referendum, as to all the various aspects of what the referendum is all about.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
I appreciate the question of my hon. friend who I think was suggesting the Government of Canada perhaps expend some money for the translation and distribution of a book written by a member of Parliament. Were my friend from Etobicoke-Lakeshore not a member of Parliament, I think it might be a subject worth considering. However he is an author and does receive royalties so I am not sure it would be appropriate.
It is a very useful layman's guide to the history and use of referendums. While I took issue with his argument on definitions, I found it very useful in understanding the issue myself. He had written an earlier, perhaps more learned tome which is a scholarly work on referendums. It is heavily footnoted and perhaps not readily assimilated by the layman.
I would remind my hon. friend his suggestion has merit, but beyond the present situation there are provisions in this bill that would provide for the review of this legislation over a predetermined period. Maybe at that time, as we deal with the question of referendum legislation in a more mature way, a long-term education program could take place.
I agree with my friend there is probably little understanding of how the conventional electoral process works, but we are being thrust into a totally new situation and some kind of public education program would probably be well in order.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I reiterate before this House how proud I am to be a Canadian. The number of noteworthy projects is growing throughout this country.
Here is one that exemplifies the level of co-operation between provincial governments and the industry, again emphasizing the efficiency of the federal system. The first maritime petroleum production system is being put into operation today. Most likely this project will be held up as an example all over the world because it is unique in that it will allow to search for small oil and gas reserves off the east coast.
For the first time in Canadian history, we are witnessing the coming into operation of a maritime oil production system with a yield of 30,000 barrels per day. Like other light substances, petroleum would evaporate quickly in the event of a spill. Besides, a review of the environmental studies reflect support for this project.
I reaffirm my pride of belonging to such a prosperous and vigourous country. This great track record only strengthened me in my resolve to never do away with my Canada-wide assets.

Mr. Speaker, a veteran and old age pensioner in my constituency of Surrey North, Arthur Cain, is typical of seniors in Canada.
They now pay the 7 per cent GST on almost everything they buy and some have had their pensions clawed back by the Mulroney government. Yet, their old age pension increase is a meagre 37 cents a month.
Mr. Cain is also typical of seniors in that he holds the Prime Minister personally responsible for the financial difficulties he is now facing.
Mr. Cain also resents that the Prime Minister will retire with a pension far greater than any public pension paid to Canadian seniors.
Mr. Cain has decided that he wants to show disgust by donating his 37 cents a month to the Prime Minister. I have in my possession a cheque made out to Brian Mulroney for no dollars and 37 cents-

Just a moment please. We have some precedents. Members' statements are not to be used to carry out a personal attack against any other members of the House. I am sure the hon. member would want to be reminded of that.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to inform the House about an artist in my riding who has completed a painting called Canadian Bouquet.
It depicts all the provincial and territorial floral emblems of Canada. My constituent hopes his painting will make a difference as we celebrate our nation's 125th birthday.
He wanted something symbolic that shows all provinces and territories together. It represents a unified Canada. It illustrates the natural beauty Canada offers.
Already the response has been overwhelming, with over 300 prints sold to raise money for charities across the country.
I congratulate Mr. Reynolds for his pride in Canada. He feels Canadians have to get out and take action rather than sit back and wait for events to unfold.
He related the painting to how one sends flowers when someone is sick. In this case, the flowers are going to Canada, which Reynolds sees as a little sick now, but with enough strength to recover. We do not want the Canadian bouquet with petals lying on the ground.
June 4, 1992

The award-winning artist, Michael Reynolds, urges all of us to celebrate Canada. It is a beautiful country.
In closing, Mr. Speaker, on behalf of Mr. Reynolds, I would like to present you with one of the prints.

Mr. Speaker, recently many women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer and who live in the riding I represent have asked me to speak out on their behalf. Given the facts of this terrible disease, I feel compelled to do so.
Consider the following: Treatment techniques have not changed in 30 years and the effects of the treatment make women very ill and unable to properly care for their families. Over-all mortality rates have remained unchanged in 30 years, despite improvements in early detection techniques. The incident rate of breast cancer has increased tremendously from one in twenty Canadian women in 1960 to one in nine in 1990. In 1991, there were 5,000 deaths from breast cancer compared with 161 for AIDS. Funding for breast cancer is only $750 per death, compared with $458,000 per AIDS death.
From a woman's point of view, breast cancer is exclusively suffered by women. Women feel research dollars and results are insignificant compared to what has been committed for other diseases.
I am today urging the federal government, despite all the financial pressures it faces, to increase research dollars for breast cancer and to do all it can to support those 40 Canadian women a day who are diagnosed. They deserve more.

Mr. Speaker, as you know, this is National Access Awareness Week. It is dedicated to increasing awareness in the general population about issues of particular concern to people with disabilities. Many barriers prevent Canadians with disabilities from participating fully in the mainstream of Canadian life.
At present, we have Bill C-78 before the House, a piece of legislation which attempts to address a number
of those concerns but which also has a number of flaws in it which I hope will be corrected at the second reading stage of debate.
There is much more to be done in the areas of employment, transportation, broadcasting and in the area of the Criminal Code and access to information, just to name a few.
Several years ago when the standing committee on human rights raised a number of concerns that we had around the House of Commons, Mr. Speaker, you were fast off your feet to correct those concerns.
It seems to me that members on the government side should be as quick on their feet to correct these other outstanding problems.

Mr. Speaker, the St. Andrew's Church of Ottawa, located in my riding, is in the forefront of the fight against poverty.
In 1991, the church began the Partnership Against Poverty program with a mandate to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000. The program unites the efforts of politicians, both national and provincial, as well as members of the business community, various church denominations and other community organizations.
The partnership program encourages the development of co-operative food bank clubs, community garden clubs and family nutrition programs, otherwise known as collective kitchens.
St. Andrew's Church is also hosting a worship service for the Grand Orange Lodge of Canada next week. These men and women will be coming from coast to coast for a national convention.
The lodge's mandate includes a commitment to charitable endeavours, in particular, cancer research. The Ottawa region has historical significance for Orange Lodge members who count among their membership such eminent Canadians as Prime Minister John A. Macdonald.
I would like to welcome Grand Orange Lodge members to Ottawa and wish them a productive conference and enjoyable stay.

June 4, 1992

Mr. Speaker, there is a special jewel located within my constituency of Portage-Interlake in Manitoba. The jewel is known as Hecla Island. In the summer, it sparkles; in the winter, it shines.
My constituents and I want Hecla Island, currently a Manitoba provincial park, to join the roster of national parks across Canada. We want this to occur sooner, not later.
I have made a request to the Minister of the Environment to visit Hecla Island this summer to view the splendour and the beauty of this unique area with his own eyes.
Canada's national parks have world-wide recognition and reputation. Hecla Island will be a valuable addition to the system of national treasures, truly a crown jewel of national parks.

For years, the people of eastern Prince Edward Island have asked the government to make needed repairs to harbours and wharfs and for years, their calls have fallen on deaf ears.
However, the people of St. John's West seem to speak the language the minister can understand. More money was spent on one wharf in St. John's West in one year than was spent on 28 wharfs in Cardigan riding for the last five years combined.
The time has come for the minister to realize that there are more people who need small craft harbour work than his constituents.
I call upon the minister to be fair to the fishermen of Cardigan and make sure the work to small craft harbours that needs to be done gets done.

Mr. Speaker, the mining industry, which used to be one of our worst
polluters, is becoming a leader in respecting the environment. Mines are planning to invest nearly $500 millions in the environment.
Mr. Jean Roberge, the assistant director of the Quebec Metal Mining Association stated that the Quebec mining industry as a whole, and not only big companies like Noranda, went green between the spring and the fall of 1988 and that we are just starting to notice the effects of this shift.
Quebec mines also have the best track record in Canada for respecting the environment, according to directors at Environment Canada.
Back in 1988, the officials of the Quebec Metal Mining Association developed an "environment savings plan" based on the RRSP system to fight pollution during the life cycle of a mine.
The Association has now published the "environmental bill of health of the industry", the first one ever in North America, and it is arousing interest in Europe. The Quebec government is presently distributing it at the earth summit in Rio.

Mr. Speaker, the beginning of summer is traditionally the time when Canada salutes its seniors, those older Canadians who helped shape this great country and who share our vision of a prosperous and united future for Canada.
Each province and territory has planned activities and events from late May until the end of June in order to mark the substantial and varied contributions that our older citizens make to this country.
Canadians young and old are taking the time to acknowledge the solid foundation that older people have laid for the society we enjoy today.
As I speak, a number of activities and events are taking place in my home province of Saskatchewan under the theme "Canada's Heritage: Bridging the Generations".
June 4, 1992

It is with great pride and enthusiasm that I urge all members, and indeed all Canadians, to join with their communities in celebrating the achievements of our seniors.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on March 14 this year, the ITAC committee (Industry, Tourism, Agriculture and Commerce) of the United Counties of Prescott and Russell sent a letter to the Prime Minister stating the following facts:
That eastern Ontario has suffered a substantial loss of industrial jobs and that the unemployment rate in our communities in eastern Ontario is twice the national average;
That a number of federal and provincial programs have been cancelled, "thanks" to this government;
That the federal government closed its regional development office for eastern Ontario; and
That the federal government is responsible for social and economic development assistance to disadvantaged regions like ours.
I support the demands of the United Counties of Prescott and Russell, and I want to ask the government to establish a regional development program for eastern Ontario in order to help Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, Stormont-Dundas,	Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke
and other ridings in dire need of assistance.

Mr. Speaker, last Tuesday evening, Andrew Des Lauriers, a North York fire captain, was trapped in a tragic blaze in Don Mills. He was put on life support at Toronto General Hospital but despite the hopes and prayers of family and colleagues, Andrew died last night.
I want to convey my condolences to his family and friends. I want to pay tribute to Andrew and all firefighters across Canada for their bravery and dedication.
My son-in-law, Mark Zaorski, has been a fire-fighter in North York for eight years. He was one of the dozens of fire-fighters trying to contain this tragic blaze.
Fire-fighters are always ready to protect our lives and property, putting their own lives at risk time and time again. Canadians owe these men and women much gratitude and respect.

Mr. Speaker, farmers are being sent a bill for a $41 million mistake made by the federal government.
The government paid out interim cheques under the Western Grain Stabilization Program about a year ago, based on a guess on how much the farmers' crops would be worth for the last three years. It was not until last August when the program ended that it took a second look and found its mistake.
With the Saskatchewan election pending no decision was made. But now, farmers who had no say in how much they received from the program in the first place are being billed and not being told why. Even farmers who had left the land in 1989 are receiving bills of up to $750.
The grains and oilseeds minister acknowledges this is a difficult time to be asking farmers for cash. He claims, however, the government has to collect and has given farmers until July 15 in which to respond.
Last year's deficit was $2 billion more than estimated. Does this mean other Canadians will be receiving bills demanding repayment for the government's overspending too?

Mr. Speaker, the week of June 1 to 7 has been proclaimed Sun Awareness Week in Canada by the Canadian Dermatology Association.
In an effort to stem the ever-increasing number of people developing skin cancer, Health and Welfare Canada and the Canadian Dermatology Association are reminding Canadians of the need to protect against over-exposure to the sun.

June 4, 1992
Oral Questions
Since sun damage to the skin usually begins in childhood and every sunburn and sun-tan harms the skin and the damage is cumulative, this is especially directed toward parents and young children.
Health and Welfare Canada is preparing an issues paper entitled "Preventing Skin Cancer: It's Up To You". It will be available soon and will be widely circulated so all Canadians can be better informed on this issue.

Mr. Speaker, according to the Globe and Mail, 35 ridiculous Tory members of Parliament, who call themselves the Caucus Committee on Family Issues, are proud that they are responsible for killing a national day care program.
They are proud and believe that the Charter of Rights and Freedoms undermines Canada and they also hold the silly view that social policy in this country goes too far in helping people. It does not surprise me that Tory dinosaurs believe this.
What does shock me is that according to this article, they are supported in their views by the minister of energy, the communications minister, the minister for privatization, the minister of small businesses, the minister of science and the minister for external relations.
Do we really have six cabinet ministers in this country who think we would be better off if women did not work outside the home? Welcome to the world of Dan Quayle's Canada.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Small Businesses.
Documents possessed by the government and released today say this about the Westray coal mine. I quote from the documents: "The interpreted structure is recognized
to contain considerable uncertainty-The mine ventilation section, which describes the results of the methane desorption test does not give one confidence-Three, based upon experience elsewhere in the world zones around faults made of elevated spontaneous combustion risks, the seam's thickness also constitute an increased spontaneous combustion risk".
Knowing of those risks, each and every one of those, did the minister responsible exercise his right under the agreement which was consummated by the Government of Canada, the Bank of Nova Scotia and Curragh Resources to do inspections of that mine? If so, will the minister explain to the House as to what those inspection reports said to him?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the first and most important statement one must make about the CANMET report from which he quotes is the study itself concluded that the proposal for a mine at Westray had no major failings. That was its conclusion.
The report was clear about some of the challenges that should be dealt with, the challenges that could be dealt with and therefore the proposal had no major failings. The report also notes that the mine would operate under a Nova Scotia Department of Mines and Energy mining lease.
What does that mean? That means the lease would not be given unless it contained clauses of what the owner can and cannot do. Finally, the federal government's contracts between the mine developer and its lenders required that the company fully comply with all Nova Scotia mining laws and regulations.
What happened was the federal government decided to guarantee the loan based upon an assessment that this was a technically feasible mine and that the challenges could be met. The mining leases to be granted by the province of Nova Scotia would make sure that all provincial regulations were complied with and, of course, we ensured on a regular basis that they were complied with.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader

June 4, 1992

The minister himself has said in this House that the firm's primary role was to monitor the levels and cost of coal production. The minister also had a binding legal document allowing the minister to inspect the mines. You know, Mr. Speaker, the hon. member raising his voice does not make his point any differently than he did two weeks ago. There is nothing new in his question. It is the same question; he will get the same answer.

What we did, and we did very carefully, was to make sure that compliance certificates were issued by the mining engineering consultants, and they were issued. In fact, I think that was responsible for the federal govern-

ment to do it. I have tabled with the documents today what those certificates contain.
Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands-
Canso): Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Small Business.

Section 7, subsection (i) of this agreement authorizes the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology to carry out inspections of this project to ensure that the project is being carried out in accordance with prudent business management and good mining practices.
My question to the minister is this: In light of his previous answers, is he satisfied that good mining practices, including adequate provisions for safety, were carried out by Curragh Resources? If so, does he accept on behalf of his government its responsibility to provide up to $85 million to the banks in the event that this mine is not reopened?

Mr. Speaker, today it is possible because we have tabled the documents to answer my hon. friend's question in some detail.
First of all let me quote from the documents. This is the loan agreement document: "Prior to each loan advance Curragh must certify"-this is the document that was tabled this morning-"that all government approvals required to be obtained under the Curragh agreement have been duly obtained and are in full force and effect".
This is further supported by an independent engineer's certificate which includes certification of government approvals and compliance with laws. I can read all of those if the hon. member would like, and I will in answering a supplementary if he likes.
What we put in place through this contract was a situation where there would be compliance with all provincial regulations and this we did and certified monthly.
Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands -
Canso): Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is for the same minister.

Oral Questions
The federal government had numerous reports warning of high methane levels at the foord seam. The federal government's own agreement with Curragh Resources and the Bank of Nova Scotia authorizes it to carry out inspections of these mines. The federal government is on the hook by this agreement for up to $85 million.
How can the minister justify to the taxpayers of Canada, not to mention the families of the 26 dead miners, the failure of his government to carry out inspections to ensure that this mine and the government's investment was secure?

Mr. Speaker, the logic of the hon. member is that if there are some challenges that have to be inspected by the province that he does not think the province can do, the federal government should take it over. Following the member's logic, the federal government should move in and take over all the schools. That is really the logic of what he is saying.
It may be a good idea. Essentially, he is suggesting that we not abide by provincial jurisdiction. This we did. They inspected on a very regular basis and we received monthly certifications that they were doing so.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. Of the 2,000 pages of information released today on the Westray mine, there is a document apparently provided to cabinet entitled Westray Coal Inc., Pictou County Coal Project, Technical Review. This report stressed serious safety concerns about operating the mine. I will quote the section quoted formerly by a member about the mine ventilation section. In -this report it says, and I quote: "does not give one confidence".

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Prime Minister. I cite some of his recent quotes before and after a visit to Washington.

June 4, 1992

Mr. Speaker, Ambassador Burney has registered very strongly the objections of the Government of Canada to Secretary Franklin in the United States in regard to what we believe is a side-swipe action, very counterproductive and quite unacceptable to the Government of Canada.

Because of the free trade agreement and the independent dispute settlement mechanism, we are able to envisage the future with some confidence in regard to this action as, for example, most recently we did when we won a most important decision on behalf of Canadian agricultural producers on the question of pork.

Oral Questions
was not initiated by the administration. It is an action initiated by the American steel industry.

interesting bill. I have not fully digested it. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, both you and the majority of members of this House of Commons will know that since I was first elected three and a half years ago, one of the issues I have brought to the floor of this House and I raise at every opportunity, both within this House and in the Canadian community at large, is the issue of violence against women.
Earlier today, the member for Broadview-Greenwood told this House that I made statements that imputed his motives and impeded him in his work as a member of Parliament. The record will show that is simply not the case. At no point in my statement yesterday did I impute motives to the member or say that he acted out of any malicious intent.
What he did in publishing the addresses of shelters for battered women in the Toronto area was certainly wrong, but I never said or implied that he acted out of an intent to endanger lives. I want to quote from what I said: "Shelters for battered women give out their phone numbers but not their addresses because it would endanger the lives of women and children". The member published and distributed shelter addresses without consulting them. This is true. Abusive men have followed and killed their partners and have also killed shelter workers in transition homes. This is true. The member said that millions of dollars were being spent on shelters and that we are advocating that women go to places that are not secure.
The alternative is staying in an abusive situation. Shelters are not secure when abusive men find out where they are. The member said the addresses were already public information. But there is a difference between finding the addresses at the public library after research and circulating them to thousands of people.
Most organizations on the list do not publicly give out their addresses. They are trying to erase public records of their addresses and publish only their phone numbers.
The member has actually missed the point of my statement which was, as I clearly stated, to urge all members of Parliament to consult with women's groups in their ridings before sending out information on violence against women. The member's troubles over this matter could have been avoided had he contacted the groups he listed beforehand.
I maintain my recommendation to all members of this House to consult with groups in their ridings as to what is an appropriate tool for education on this matter and what to enclose with it in terms of support systems available in their communities for survivors of violence.
Not all members have the experience of working in a shelter for battered women. I understand they are therefore unaware of the effects some of their actions may have on those women and children. But a review of my statement will show no inaccuracies whatsoever.
I had hoped that my statement would be taken in a constructive manner by all members of Parliament. Instead, I find that the member seems to not have learned from that.
Violence against women is an extremely important issue to me and to many members in this House. It is my responsibility to urge members to avoid the situation the member for Broadview-Greenwood put himself into for the sake of abused women and children in all our ridings across Canada.
June 4, 1992

What he did was wrong, publishing the addresses of shelters for battered women. It was wrong. It did put women into increased danger. It was not intentionally wrong, I understand that, but it was wrong all the same.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess this has some relevance to the debate and I will answer the question, since I think my friend asked it in sincerity.
June 4, 1992

The government is not prepared to put a measure which is already in place to a referendum.
Second, the act implementing the goods and services tax was not submitted to a referendum of the Canadian people because it was part of the election platform of this party in 1988. I can recall being asked numerous questions about it as we went door to door in 1988. It is my belief the Progressive Conservative Party and the government which had a mandate from 1984 to 1988 got a renewed mandate in part because of its commitment to repeal the manufacturers' sales tax and replace it with a consumer-based tax.
I will concede the precise nature of the tax was not defined at that point. An all-party committee subsequently recommended the form of tax which we now have. Representatives of the hon. member's own party participated in that. That has now been implemented and is behind us. If the people of Canada do not approve of the tax, that will be one of the issues on which they will judge the government in the next general election.
That is a matter suitable for adjudication in a general election. Constitutional matters may be open to referendum under certain circumstances, but I do not believe there is a demand, nor should there be a demand, in this country for submitting conventional pieces of legislation to the referendum process.

Mr. Speaker, it is indeed a singular privilege to speak on third reading of Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada, and reflect the sentiments and wishes of my constituents from the riding of Winnipeg North.
At the outset I would like to commend the government for recognizing at last the need for a national referendum, which was proposed by the Liberal Party a little over a year ago on April 21, 1991, when my leader formally announced our party's nine-point plan for Canada's new Constitution.
It is high time we referred Canada to all Canadians and not fragmented portions for their final say. A national referendum will give Canadians outside Quebec a chance to tell their fellow citizens in Quebec they are important and essential to the country we know and love. It will give Quebecers a chance to say yes to all other Canadians from sea to sea.
The Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau, a former
Government Orders
Liberal Prime Minister of our country, once said: "The foundation of a nation is will". I therefore say let the people express this foundation of Canada.
The referendum bill proposed by this government however has some remaining problems. While they call it a referendum, what the Conservatives are really proposing is more of a plebiscite.
A referendum and a plebiscite are not the same, although not infrequently mistakenly interchanged in usage. Allow me to cite a reference book entitled Lawmaking by the People: Referendums and Plebiscites in Canada, by one of our own colleagues, the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore. I quote from page 13 of his book:
The main difference between the two voting devices is therefore that a plebiscite is essentially a public opinion poll, but a referendum automatically binds a government to enact a law (or to refrain from doing so) according to the voters' wishes.
Indeed, what the government is really proposing is more of a plebiscite. What the government has really proposed, if it were not to be bound by the results of the vote, is a plebiscite in the context of this definition. If it were so, it would be the most costly public opinion poll at a cost to Canadian taxpayers of some $100 million at a time of very high unemployment and intense suffering on the part of millions of Canadians without jobs.
But there will be greater suffering without a united Canada. There will be greater disappointment if every Canadian voter is not given the opportunity to express her or his will, her or his voice in a referendum.
I am therefore saddened that the Leader of the New Democratic Party said her party would not support this referendum bill. My sadness was joined by alarm and grave concern when I heard the separatists in this chamber applaud the New Democratic leader and call her courageous. It takes courage to insist that Canadians be given the opportunity to express their will on Canada's new Constitution.
As my leader has repeatedly said: "The Constitution belongs to the people and all Canadians should have the final say on any constitutional reform package". My leader had a vision and the courage to express that vision on this issue a little more than a year ago.

June 4, 1992
Government Orders
It is true the bill as we have it today is not a perfect one. Our caucus however was pleased when the government accepted many amendments we introduced. I still have some concerns. The government has not made a commitment to not pass the constitutional reform package without the clear majority from each of the four regions of Canada: the Atlantic, Ontario, the west and Quebec.
The government must commit itself to respect not only a national majority but a clear majority from each of the four regions of our nation. The government should not use this bill as a tool to simply manipulate the provinces into agreement. The referendum should be an essential component of the decision-making on the future of Canada.
Let the people of our great democratic country express themselves and determine their future directly on a vital issue such as the issue facing the country today.
In the spirit of our federal country and our proud tradition of protecting minorities while respecting majorities, we should ensure real agreement across the country by demanding that the referendum vote pass in each region of the nation.
If we ask Quebecers with other Canadians if they want to journey further with us but provide no guarantee that we will not swallow their answers in the majority of the rest of the country, what kind of signal are we giving them?
Quebec, like the west and the other unique regions of Canada, must know that its distinctive perspective and separate importance to the country is cherished by the promise that its will will carry weight.
Each region must be able to affirm Canada and we must affirm the importance of that in any referendum we propose. Also, it is important that its mechanism be fair, and that the people of each region of Canada who must choose whether or not to vote and how to do so know that their opinions will be treated with all due respect.
Indeed, the referendum has to be fair not only to each of the regions but also with respect to each side of the question. Once again, the government refuses to provide a framework for fairness. Do we want money to decide the question of our country's future, or will we provide the essential structure of contribution limits to allow the real will of the people to be expressed?
As in any election in Canada, fairness must be ensured by keeping the battle ground level. Spending limits and, more important, contribution limits guard the right of Canadians to make their own decisions and express them unhindered by the absence of wealth or unduly purchased by it.
There should not be an illusion of support due to wealth alone.
I am glad that the government has listened to some opposition concerns, the concerns of the Liberal caucus at amendment time, accepting a number of our amendments.
Last, the government's bill does not ensure fairness in another dimension of administration of a referendum, the development of the question to be asked. The government proposes a few days of parliamentary debate on the wording of the question which would only allow for amendment, not participation, in the wording by opposition parties.
In an issue as important as the future of our country should not we, as members of Parliament, abandon our disagreements and allow the people of Canada instead to benefit from our differences by consulting together to present them with the most clear and helpful question possible?
The Prime Minister has assured reporters that his lack of popularity would not interfere with the determining of the future of this country through a referendum. He is willing to trust the people of Canada to put aside partisan political considerations to express truly their will for Canada. The people are to transcend partisanship in this essential issue but the elected members of this government, unwilling to let their control of events slip in the slightest, even for the sake of Canada, are not.
This is not consistent nor does it give Canada and Canadians their best chance before a referendum.
The moral force of popular will is the essence of a referendum. Whether it is legally or not legally binding is merely a debate on legal technicality. Moral force goes beyond the confines of technicalities. Moral force is at a higher level, on a higher pedestal. Moral force expresses, in the context of the national unity debate before the country, the will of the people, the will of all Canadians from sea to sea. In turn moral power or strength depends on the fairness of the process, how the referendum is conducted and its results interpreted and accepted.
June 4, 1992

At this juncture I would like to mention the efforts of two Canadian scientists, Dr. Jon Gerrard, a professor of paediatrics at the University of Manitoba Faculty of Medicine, and Dr. Jean-Pierre Despres, a professor at the University of Laval in Quebec City. These two scientists, along with 2,200 others from coast to coast, have signed petitions for a unified country. These scientists come from different cultures and speak different languages and yet they see the need for Canadian unity to ensure the future of science and education in Canada and thereby ensure the future of Canada itself.
Let me quote from the resolution our Canadian scientists have asked me to table in this House:
Be it resolved that we as Canadians rededicate ourselves to a'
renewed spirit of co-operation, to build a nation where tolerance,
diversity and caring for others are hallmarks.
Let this spirit of co-operation to build a renewed nation begin in this House today. Let us have the courage to consult with all Canadians. Let us, the elected representatives of the people, irrespective of political stripes, listen to their will and understand their hearts and minds. It has been said salus populi suprema lex est, the will of the people is the supreme law. Indeed the foundation of a nation is will as I said in the beginning.
I believe Canadians have the will to hold their country tight, to keep it from breaking. Do we have the will in Parliament to let them show their love for this land? I pray to God we do, Mr. Speaker.

I do not know, at this point, if I will abstain from voting or if I will support this legislation, but one thing is certain: I want to be clearly understood. My position is unequivocal: Never, and I mean never, will I recognize a referendum through which a majority from outside Quebec would impose its views on that province. This
means that I would have hoped to see in the bill this issue of regional veto.
I am speaking on behalf of my province. I know that Quebec is a region. I leave it up to Canadians to define their regions. I remember an hon. member who wished that Canada would be divided into five regions. This reminds me of our history class in school when we were taught that there were five regions in Canada. Today, others see four regions. I do not have to get involved in this debate. I will talk on behalf of my region.
I want the record to state clearly that, personally, I will never accept that the rest of Canada dictate its views to Quebec. I will go even farther by saying that I would fight anybody from any political party, including mine, who would believe or who would want people to believe that we can, through a Canadian majority, impose something on my province that it does not want.
Mr. Speaker, there is no point in making a long speech. This is a well-thought comment that I wanted to make in the House.

Mr. Speaker, I listened attentively to the remarks made by the member for Saint-Denis. He knows all the admiration I have for him. I agree with what he said. I feel that, as a confederation, we should not, by a pan-Canadian vote, impose a pan-Canadian decision on any province.
I go even further than the member for Saint-Denis. I feel that Alberta surely has the right to be heard. It presently has before its legislature a referendum bill. I really feel that, while we form a confederation, an over-all view should not be imposed on any region or province.
That was by way of a comment.

In addition, there were other suggestions to make sure that the poor, the native people, the ethnic communities of this country and the women who may not have funding can take part in a referendum campaign. That is if they have some means of participating. Unfortunately, under the rules that the government put forward, it is basically a big-buck campaign. If you are rich, you campaign and others are excluded.
The Liberal Party did not get any of these major amendments. One of the things I noticed as I was going through the votes last night was that there is very little time left. We want a referendum. We want a fair referendum in the New Democratic Party, but a lot of the amendments that the Liberals voted with the government on last night, time after time after time, ensure that there will not be a fair referendum.
I ask him: "Why did you vote with the government so many times last night on important amendments? Second, since you did not achieve any of your main goals, how can you support such unfair legislation?" We want the people to decide. Why support this legislation?

Mr. Speaker, unfortunately, in the past few days some members have not acted so eloquently and in a way that befits Quebecers.

June 4, 1992
Government Orders
We are at third reading of Bill C-81, the referendum bill. Why are we dealing with a referendum bill today? We must go back to Meech when a premier, by not respecting his signature, created a major constitutional deadlock and the five conditions for Quebec to return to the constitutional fold were not met. As a result, the whole country was in a major impasse.
A year later, the Prime Minister of Canada, decided to try to solve the constitutional problem again. To do so, despite the strong and bitter criticism from many opponents, he created the Beaudoin-Edwards Committee. This committee had a specific purpose: to see how the constitutional amending formula could be changed and also to look into the subject of referendums. We on this committee, chaired by two eminent colleagues, Senator Beaudoin and my fellow member, Mr. Edwards, made the following recommendation: We thought that the federal authorities-
They have left.

Indeed, our colleagues have left. We thought that the federal authorities should table a referendum bill in the Canadian Parliament. This referendum would be optional. It would be up to the authorities to use it as required. Given the heterogeneous nature of the country, we thought that the bill should provide for a double majority, a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions.
This referendum would not change the Constitution of Canada. Its result would have a political, not a legal value. It would not bind the two levels of government, but it would send an eloquent message.
That was one of the recommendations of the Beaudoin-Edwards Committee, because it was felt that in case of a deadlock, we would ultimately have to go to the people.
The Prime Minister subsequently appointed a second constitutional committee, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee, to prepare an in-depth analysis of the changes that would have to be made in the Canadian Constitution to rally the provinces, the First Ministers and the people of Canada around the same set of constitutional proposals.
I had the privilege of working on this committee as well. This is what our committee had to say: "We recommend that a federal law be enacted, if deemed appropriate by the Government of Canada, to enable the federal government, at its discretion, to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal, either to confirm the existence of a national consensus or to facilitate the adoption of the required amending resolutions".
Both committees recommended that there should be a mechanism, in case of a deadlock, that would allow us to go to the people.
Where are we now? The First Ministers and their representatives met over a period of several weeks and are trying, on the basis of the Beaudoin-Dobbie report's recommendations, to formulate constitutional proposals that will respond to the expectations of all Canadians, not only Quebecers, and of all the provinces.
However, we must still deal with the, perhaps not very palatable but still very real, possibility that we may be faced with a deadlock. If that happens, what is our responsibility as parliamentarians? At the very least, we must ensure legislation is in place that would enable Canadians across the country to say how they see their country and what they want from their country. Under our democratic system, the right of First Ministers to let this country break up because there is a deadlock is superseded by the fundamental right of Canadians to say what they want from their country and whether they agree with the proposed changes.
The government has tabled legislation, Bill C-81, which provides for referendums on the Constitution of Canada. I have examined the bill, and there are many aspects I do not like. For instance, I felt it was very important, in a Canadian referendum, to be able to respect the differences that exist across the country, especially in Quebec, which since 1982 has not been a party to this constitutional agreement and which as a distinct society asked for certain specific powers and got no for an answer as a result of the demise of Meech.
I would have liked to see a double majority, in other words provision in the legislation that requires a majority both across Canada and in each of Canada's four major regions. The west must say yes, Ontario must say yes, the
June 4, 1992

maritimes must say yes and Quebec as well. This is not only a matter of vision but also a way to avoid the kind of situation that caused the demise of Meech Lake, when a single First Minister, because he refused to sign his name, prevented the Constitution from being amended and Quebec from turning to the constitutional fold.
We could have the same situation if a First Minister were to say: "I am committed to respecting the decision of my province in a referendum". In that case, we might get the same result as we did after Meech, which means Quebec would not be able to go after its veto, with all the consequences that would entail.
I had a second amendment I wanted the House of Commons to approve. It was about spending ceilings which would ensure that yes committees or no committees would never have an undue advantage over each other, based on the funds available to each side.
I would refer to it as an inequity situation in a referendum. That is the context in which I first tabled amendments for consideration before the legislative committee, amendments not unlike many that were considered at the time of the 1980 referendum in Quebec. Then I tabled the same amendments before this House so that they could be disposed of. Our Speaker ruled that the amendments-not just mine, but those of opposition members as well; there were five in all along that line-were out of order in that they went beyond the scope of the bill. And there is no going back on this ruling of the Speaker.
There is nothing stopping our Prime Minister or opposition leaders from giving the people of Canada the assurance that the Canadian majority will not decide for Quebec. Nothing is stopping our Prime Minister and opposition leaders from making such commitments.
On the other hand, votes were taken in this House yesterday on the amendments relating to the ceiling on expenditures as well as and the yes and no umbrellas and these were defeated. One hundred and eleven members voted against and 68 for the amendment I had tabled to ensure that, if a referendum were to be held in Canada, it would be the fairest possible. That being said, I suggest that democracy means allowing a member to put forward
Government Orders
proposals to amend a bill and letting his colleagues decide, based on their own knowledge and conscience.
In that context, what is in the best interest of Canada? Indeed, we may decide we would rather have no bill than to have one that is flawed. In that case, what would happen? The result would be that, in the event of a constitutional impasse, we would be stuck. I maintain that we are better off with a flawed piece of legislation than to have no way of consulting the people of Canada in the event of an impasse.
That is no piece of legislation. It is a hold-up on democracy.
There are two peoples in Canada.
It is not worth it. It is a waste of money.

Moreover, if we do not have a referendum act, the people of Canada could well be the first to criticize us the most sharply for having failed, as members of Parliament, to afford them protection in the event of an impasse. And that is our duty as parliamentarians.
I could rise in this House tonight-as a matter of fact it would look good if Jean-Pierre Blackburn rose and voted no-and vote against this bill because it does not provide for a ceiling on expenditures as I hoped it would. It would look good-
Our hon. friend will get a chance to speak in a moment, if he would just wait his turn. It would look good indeed. But would it be the responsible thing to do?
I sat on the Beaudoin-Edwards committee where members of this House did recommend that there be a referendum act. Later, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee recommended the same thing. In that context, we do need a referendum act. We do because of the threat of an impasse. That is also why I intend to support the principle of this referendum bill, as imperfect as it may be, as I did by the way in second reading. Unlike the members from the Bloc Quebecois, however, I suited my action to my words. I tabled amendments and attended the legislative committee for that purpose. This piece of legislation is not perfect but there could be a deadlock and we do not have the right, as parliamentarians, not to provide Canadians with the tool that they would need in such a case. It is in that context that we must make a decision and take our responsibilities.
We have the right and the privilege to make amendments. Members of Parliament have the right and the privilege to vote on these amendments.
